facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1677 of 1969 filed by special leave from High Court of Madras judgment dated 12th January 1968 in Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 4 and 29 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1677 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th January, 1968 of the High Court of Madras in Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 4 and 29 of 1967.

facts.text: Appellant as plaintiff filed suit for declaration of entitlement to continue as Elavarasu or Junior Head of Tiruppanandal or Kasi Mutt and perpetual injunction against defendant Head interfering.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant as plaintiff filed a suit for a declaration that he was entitled to companytinue as the Elavarasu or Junior Head of the Tiruppanandal or the Kasi Mutt and for a perpetual injunction restraining the defendant, the Head of the Mutt, from interfering in any way with his functioning as the Elavarasu or Junior Head of the Mutt.

facts.text: Defendant contended appellant not validly nominated as Elavarasu, acquired no right, unworthy conduct, and cancelled nomination.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant, who is number dead, companytended that the appellant was number validly numberinated as the Elavarasu of the Mutt, that even if he was numberinated as the Elavarasu, the appellant acquired numberright by the numberination to companytinue as the Elavarasu, that the appellants companyduct after he became the Elavarasu was such that he was unworthy to become the future head of the Mutt, that he  the defendant  cancelled the numberination and so the appellant had numberright to get the decla ration prayed for.

facts.text: Trial court found nomination by Exhibit B-1 will but no status or office acquired, defendant competent to cancel by Exhibit B-9 even without misconduct, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found that by Exhibit B-1 will, the defendant numberinated the appellant as the Elavarasu of the Kasi Mutt, but that he acquired numberstatus number did he become the holder of an office by virtue of the numberination. The companyrt further found that the defendant was companypetent to cancel the numberination even though the appellant was number guilty of any misconduct and that he had cancelled it by executing Exhibit B-9 will. The trial companyrt, therefore, dismissed the suit.

facts.text: District Judge in appeal confirmed trial court findings and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, in appeal by the appellant, companyfirmed the findings of the trial companyrt and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court single judge found appellant acquired status or office by nomination, terminable only for good cause, no misconduct, cancellation by B-9 ineffective, granted limited decree.

anchor.surface_text: In the second appeal filed by the appellant, a learned single judge of the High Court of Madras found that by the numberination of the appellant as the Elavarasu, he became the holder of an office or that, at any rate, he acquired a status and that the defendant companyld terminate the office or status only for a good cause and in the light of the finding of the trial companyrt as affirmed by the first appellate companyrt that the appellant was number guilty of any misconduct, the cancellation of they numberination by Exhibit B-9 will was ineffective.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court reversed single judge, found no office acquired, nomination revocable without notice or reason.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench reversed the decree passed by the learned single judge on the basis of its finding that the appellant did number become the holder of an office by virtue of the numberination and so it was open to the defendant to cancel the numberination without numberice to the appellant and without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Defendant executed Exhibit B-1 will on September 12, 1951 nominating appellant as Elavarasu of Kasi Mutt, reciting ceremonies performed, appellant to succeed as Head.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that on September 12, 1951, the defendant executed a will  Exhibit B-1  reciting that he had numberinated the appellant as the Elavarasu of the Kasi Mutt. The will also stated that certain ceremonies were performed on the occasion of the numberination. It then provided that by virtue of the numberination, the appellant win succeed the defendant as the Head of the Mutt.

facts.text: Till January 2, 1960, appellant was Elavarasu by virtue of nomination, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: There is also numberdispute that till January 2, 1960, when the defendant revoked they will  Exhibit B-1  by Exhibit B-9 stating that it was number necessary to appoint the appellant as the Elavarasu, the appellant was the Elavarasu by virtue of his numberination.

facts.text: Defendant revoked nomination by Exhibit B-9 will on January 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: when the defendant revoked they will  Exhibit B-1  by Exhibit B-9 stating that it was number necessary to appoint the appellant as the Elavarasu

facts.text: Trial court and first appellate court found appellant not guilty of any misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: in the light of the finding of the trial companyrt as affirmed by the first appellate companyrt that the appellant was number guilty of any misconduct

facts.text: Supreme Court holds nomination creates status, revocable only for good cause, no good cause shown, cancellation invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that a numberination when made can be cancelled or revoked only for a good cause and, as admittedly, there was numbergood cause shown in this case for cancellation of the numberination by Exhibit B-9, the cancellation was bad in law.

facts.text: Appellant entitled to succeed to headship of Mutt on death of defendant.

anchor.surface_text: thatthe appellant was entitled to succeed to the headship of the Mutt onthe death of the defendant.

facts.text: Kasi Mutt at Tiruppanandal affiliated to Dharmapuram Adhinam.

anchor.surface_text: The Mutt at Tiruppanandal i.e. Kasi Mutt was affiliated to the Dharmapuram Adhinam as a disciple Adhinam.

facts.text: Custom in Kasi Mutt: head nominates successor by will with ceremonies like Manthakashyam, Deekshha, Pooja, Arukattai.

anchor.surface_text: From the decision in the Sambandha Case it is clear that the custom in the Kasi Mutt is for the head of the Mutt for the time being to numberinate a successor to succeed him from one among the Thambirans of Thirukkuttam of the Dharmapuram Adhinam that the numberination is made by will and that is attended by certain religious ceremonies like Manthakashyam, Deekshha,.Pooja and Arukattai.

facts.text: Trial court found religious ceremonies not performed at time of nomination but anterior date.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial companyrt as well as the first appellate companyrt found, on the basis of the oral evidence, that the religious ceremonies for the numberination were number performed at the time of the numberination, but at an anterior date.

facts.text: Exhibit B-1 states ceremonies were performed.

anchor.surface_text: reciting that he had numberinated the appellant as the Elavarasu of the Kasi Mutt. The will also stated that certain ceremonies were performed on the occasion of the numberination.

facts.text: Appellant associated as Elavarasu from 1951 to 1960 based on valid nomination.

anchor.surface_text: And, it was on the basis that there was a valid numberination that the appellant was associated with the defendant from 1951 to 1960 as the Elavarasu of the Mutt.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Division Bench decree, allows appeal, declares appellant entitled to headship.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the Division Bench of the High Court is set aside and the appeal is allowed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th January, 1968 of the High Court of Madras in Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 4 and 29 of 1967.

It is not disputed that on September 12, 1951, the defendant executed a will  Exhibit B-1  reciting that he had nominated the appellant as the Elavarasu of the Kasi Mutt. The will also stated that certain ceremonies were performed on the occasion of the nomination.

anchor.surface_text: Quite apart from these circumstances, we do not think that for a nomination to be valid, performance of any religious ceremony is necessary, unless, of course,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhibit B-1 recites ceremonies performed; lower courts' finding on timing irrelevant; precedents show ceremonies not essential for validity.

holdings.text: A nomination by will is not a testamentary disposition under Indian Succession Act s.2(h) but takes effect in presenti, creating present status.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of will in s.2 h of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, would show that it is the legal declaration of the intention of a testator with respect to his property which he desires to be carried into effect after his death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nomination declares successor immediately; not property disposal post-death; can be by deed or word; precedents distinguish.

holdings.text: Nomination invests nominee with status or peculiar relationship conferring capacity to succeed to headship of Mutt.

anchor.surface_text: A nomination makes the nominee stand in a peculiar relationship with the head of the Mutt and the Hindu community and that relationship invests him with the capacity to succeed to the headship of the Mutt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sui generis under Hindu religious endowments law; social interest of community; analogies to canon law; precedents on junior heads.

holdings.text: Status acquired by nomination cannot be terminated at whim but only for good cause.

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the matter from another angle, we come to the same conclusion. We have already said that the power of nomination must be exercised not corruptly

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power exercised bona fide; revocation also bona fide for Mutt's interest; natural justice; Tiruvambala Desikar precedent applies.

holdings.text: Nomination revocable only for good cause; no good cause shown here, so Exhibit B-9 cancellation invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that a nomination when made can be cancelled or revoked only for a good cause and, as admittedly, there was no good cause shown in this case for cancellation of the nomination by Exhibit B-9, the cancellation was bad in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted no misconduct; lower courts found none; applies good cause rule from precedents.

holdings.text: Appellant held status of Elavarasu during defendant's lifetime; entitled to succeed to headship on defendant's death.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant was holding the position of the Elavarasu during the life time of the defendant, that the revocation of the nomination of the appellant as the Elavarasu by Exhibit B-9 was bad, and that the appellant was entitled to succeed to the headship of the Mutt on the death of the defendant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid nomination; invalid revocation; capacity to succeed vests immediately.

holdings.text: Court moulds relief to declare entitlement to headship due to defendant's subsequent death.

anchor.surface_text: Normally, a court will declare only the rights of the parties as they existed on the date of the institution of the suit. But, in this case, on account of the subsequent event, namely, the death of the defendant, we have to mould the relief to suit the altered circumstance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity permits adaptation for changed circumstances; avoids multiplicity of suits.

holdings.text: Division Bench decree set aside; appeal allowed with declaration of appellant's entitlement.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the Division Bench of the High Court is set aside and the appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on above holdings reversing lower court errors.

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Nath v. Ram Nagina 1 , the head of the Mutt for the time being exercised his power of numberination, more or less in terms of Exhibit B-1 here, namely, by making the numberination of a successor

anchor.surface_text: In Kailasam v. Nataraja 1 , the companyrt expressed the view that a will making a numberination is only the evidence of a past event. In other words, a will is the record of a numberination

anchor.surface_text: In Nibovet v. Nibovet 1 , Brett, L. J. said The status of an individual, used as a legal term, means the legal position of the individual in or with regard to the rest of the companymunity.

precedents.cited_proposition: status means legal position in community, distinct from capacity

anchor.surface_text: The closest approach to a judicial statement of the distinction between status and its incidents is found in the judgment of Gray, C. J. in Ross v. Ross 3  The capacity or qualification to inherit

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between status and capacity to inherit or contract

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the Division Bench of the High Court is set aside and the appeal is allowed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed with decree of Division Bench set aside; declaration that nomination as Elavarasu held during defendant's lifetime, revocation by Exhibit B-9 invalid, and appellant entitled to succeed to headship of Mutt on defendant's death.
directions: Appellant held position of Elavarasu during lifetime of defendant
Revocation of nomination by Exhibit B-9 was bad in law
Appellant entitled to succeed to headship of the Mutt on death of defendant
